articles.headline: In a German Tech Giant’s Fall, Charges of Lies, Spies and Missing Billions
articles.snippet: Markus Braun built Wirecard to “conquer the world,” but those aspirations attracted skeptics. Its accounting scandal has sent shock waves through Germany.
articles.abstract: Markus Braun built Wirecard to “conquer the world,” but those aspirations attracted skeptics. Its accounting scandal has sent shock waves through Germany.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the elite corridors of corporate Germany, Markus Braun had become a legend.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Christopher F. Schuetze

articles.headline: Russia Secretly Offered Afghan Militants Bounties to Kill U.S. Troops, Intelligence Says
articles.snippet: The Trump administration has been deliberating for months about what to do about a stunning intelligence assessment.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration has been deliberating for months about what to do about a stunning intelligence assessment.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American intelligence officials have concluded that a Russian military intelligence unit secretly offered bounties to Taliban-linked militants for killing coalition forces in Afghanistan — including targeting American troops — amid the peace talks to end the long-running war there, according to officials briefed on the matter.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage, Eric Schmitt and Michael Schwirtz

articles.headline: Leaders Re-examine U.S. Reopenings as Coronavirus Cases Hit Another Record
articles.snippet: Officials nationwide were rethinking their efforts to slow the virus, which the nation’s top infectious disease expert said were “not working.”
articles.abstract: Officials nationwide were rethinking their efforts to slow the virus, which the nation’s top infectious disease expert said were “not working.”
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — As coronavirus cases surge across much of the United States, leaders are urgently rethinking their strategies to curb the spread, which the nation’s top infectious disease expert said on Friday were “not working.”
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei, Sarah Mervosh and Shawn Hubler

articles.headline: EBay’s Critics Faced an Extreme Case of an Old Silicon Valley Habit
articles.snippet: Six former employees were recently named in federal charges that were an indication of the lengths some companies will go to hit back at detractors.
articles.abstract: Six former employees were recently named in federal charges that were an indication of the lengths some companies will go to hit back at detractors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, members of eBay’s private security team sent live roaches and a bloody pig mask to the home of a suburban Boston couple who published a niche e-commerce newsletter.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: The Black Officer Who Detained George Floyd Had Pledged to Fix the Police
articles.snippet: Alex Kueng is one of four former officers accused of crimes in the killing of Mr. Floyd, which happened on his third shift. His decision to join the force had frayed friendships.
articles.abstract: Alex Kueng is one of four former officers accused of crimes in the killing of Mr. Floyd, which happened on his third shift. His decision to join the force had frayed friendships.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — There were two black men at the scene of the police killing in Minneapolis last month that roiled the nation. One, George Floyd, was sprawled on the asphalt, with a white officer’s knee on his neck. The other black man, Alex Kueng, was a rookie police officer who held his back as Mr. Floyd struggled to breathe.
articles.byline: By Kim Barker

articles.headline: ‘PizzaGate’ Conspiracy Theory Thrives Anew in the TikTok Era
articles.snippet: The false theory targeting Democrats, now fueled by QAnon and teenagers on TikTok, is entangling new targets like Justin Bieber.
articles.abstract: The false theory targeting Democrats, now fueled by QAnon and teenagers on TikTok, is entangling new targets like Justin Bieber.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four minutes into a video that was posted on Instagram last month, Justin Bieber leaned into the camera and adjusted the front of his black knit beanie. For some of his 130 million followers, it was a signal.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: How the World Missed Covid-19’s Silent Spread
articles.snippet: Symptomless transmission makes the coronavirus far harder to fight. But health officials dismissed the risk for months, pushing misleading and contradictory claims in the face of mounting evidence.
articles.abstract: Symptomless transmission makes the coronavirus far harder to fight. But health officials dismissed the risk for months, pushing misleading and contradictory claims in the face of mounting evidence.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Dr. Camilla Rothe was about to leave for dinner when the government laboratory called with the surprising test result. Positive. It was Jan. 27. She had just discovered Germany’s first case of the new coronavirus.

articles.headline: ‘We Live From the Tourists’: Orlando Workers Face Virus’s Fallout
articles.snippet: The pandemic decimated central Florida’s once-booming leisure and hospitality industry. Disney World and other destinations have started to reopen, but infections in the state are surging.
articles.abstract: The pandemic decimated central Florida’s once-booming leisure and hospitality industry. Disney World and other destinations have started to reopen, but infections in the state are surging.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Four thousand phone calls.
articles.byline: By Eve Edelheit and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: How Americans Feel About the Country Right Now: Anxious. Hopeful.
articles.snippet: Exhausted and angry as they face a series of crises, many voters nevertheless remain optimistic about the future, a poll shows, viewing this moment as a chance for progress, one they can help shape.
articles.abstract: Exhausted and angry as they face a series of crises, many voters nevertheless remain optimistic about the future, a poll shows, viewing this moment as a chance for progress, one they can help shape.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amanda Vibelius, a stay-at-home mother in rural Arizona, is angry and overwhelmed.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer, Elaina Plott and Lazaro Gamio

articles.headline: After Asking Americans to Sacrifice in Shutdown, Leaders Failed to Control Virus
articles.snippet: As Covid-19 cases surge, it is clear many governors underestimated the coronavirus and rushed to reopen before their states were ready.
articles.abstract: As Covid-19 cases surge, it is clear many governors underestimated the coronavirus and rushed to reopen before their states were ready.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than four months into fighting the coronavirus in the United States, the shared sacrifice of millions of Americans suspending their lives — with jobs lost, businesses shuttered, daily routines upended — has not been enough to beat back a virus whose staying power around the world is only still being grasped.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise, Frances Robles and Louis Keene

articles.headline: How Michael Flynn’s Defense Team Found Powerful Allies
articles.snippet: A lawyer for the former national security adviser turned to the attorney general for help, and he delivered, months before a pair of appellate judges handed Mr. Flynn another legal victory.
articles.abstract: A lawyer for the former national security adviser turned to the attorney general for help, and he delivered, months before a pair of appellate judges handed Mr. Flynn another legal victory.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sidney Powell, a firebrand lawyer whose pugnacious Fox News appearances had earned her numerous private phone conversations with President Trump, sent a letter last year to Attorney General William P. Barr about her soon-to-be new client, Michael T. Flynn.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Charlie Savage and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Boeing Gets Go-Ahead for Test Flights of Its Troubled 737 Max
articles.snippet: The flights, which could begin as soon as Monday, are a major step in getting the plane flying again.
articles.abstract: The flights, which could begin as soon as Monday, are a major step in getting the plane flying again.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boeing has received Federal Aviation Administration approval to start test flights of its 737 Max to demonstrate that it can fly safely with new flight control software. The flights, which could begin as soon as Monday, represent a major step in the company’s effort to get its best-selling plane flying again.
articles.byline: By Niraj Chokshi and David Gelles

articles.headline: Spies and Commandos Warned Months Ago of Russian Bounties on U.S. Troops
articles.snippet: The recovery of large amounts of American cash at a Taliban outpost in Afghanistan helped tip off U.S. officials. It is believed that at least one U.S. troop death was the result of the bounties.
articles.abstract: The recovery of large amounts of American cash at a Taliban outpost in Afghanistan helped tip off U.S. officials. It is believed that at least one U.S. troop death was the result of the bounties.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — United States intelligence officers and Special Operations forces in Afghanistan alerted their superiors as early as January to a suspected Russian plot to pay bounties to the Taliban to kill American troops in Afghanistan, according to officials briefed on the matter. They believed at least one U.S. troop death was the result of the bounties, two of the officials said.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Adam Goldman and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: How the Trump Campaign Is Drawing Obama Out of Retirement
articles.snippet: More than three years after his exit, the 44th president of the United States is back on a political battlefield he longed to leave.
articles.abstract: More than three years after his exit, the 44th president of the United States is back on a political battlefield he longed to leave.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just after Donald J. Trump was elected president, Barack Obama slumped in his chair in the Oval Office and addressed an aide standing near a conspicuously placed bowl of apples, emblem of a healthy-snacking policy soon to be swept aside, along with so much else.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Elaina Plott

articles.headline: Marty Baron Made The Post Great Again. Now, the News Is Changing.
articles.snippet: The ultimate old-school editor is grappling with a moment of cultural reckoning.
articles.abstract: The ultimate old-school editor is grappling with a moment of cultural reckoning.
articles.lead_paragraph: Almost anyone who works in the Washington Post newsroom can look inside its publishing system, Methode, to see what stories are coming. And at the height of the furor over Brett Kavanaugh’s nomination to the Supreme Court in 2018, some who did saw a shocking article awaiting publication.
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: Three Words. 70 Cases. The Tragic History of ‘I Can’t Breathe.’
articles.snippet: The deaths of Eric Garner in New York and George Floyd in Minnesota created national outrage over the use of deadly police restraints. There were many others you didn’t hear about.
articles.abstract: The deaths of Eric Garner in New York and George Floyd in Minnesota created national outrage over the use of deadly police restraints. There were many others you didn’t hear about.
articles.lead_paragraph: The deaths of Eric Garner in New York and George Floyd in Minnesota created national outrage over the use of deadly police restraints. There were many others you didn’t hear about.
articles.byline: By Mike Baker, Jennifer Valentino-DeVries, Manny Fernandez and Michael LaForgia

articles.headline: ‘Feeling Like Death’: Inside a Houston Hospital Bracing for a Virus Peak
articles.snippet: As young patients fill new virus wards, Houston Methodist is calling nurses to work extra shifts and ramping up its testing efforts.
articles.abstract: As young patients fill new virus wards, Houston Methodist is calling nurses to work extra shifts and ramping up its testing efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Melissa Estrada had tried to be so careful about the coronavirus. For months she kept her three children at home, and she always wore a mask at the grocery store. She and her daughter even stitched face coverings for relatives and friends.
articles.byline: By Sheri Fink

articles.headline: The Video Call Is Starting. Time to Put on Your Zoom Shirt.
articles.snippet: When homebound workers need to spiff up moments before a meeting, they reach for the breakout garment of quarantine season.
articles.abstract: When homebound workers need to spiff up moments before a meeting, they reach for the breakout garment of quarantine season.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s time to log in to his first Zoom meeting of his workday, so Joe Farrell puts on a short-sleeve button-down from Brooks Brothers, in black, red and white plaid.
articles.byline: By Joel Stein

articles.headline: The Long, Unhappy History of Working From Home
articles.snippet: As the coronavirus keeps spreading, employers are convinced remote work has a bright future. Decades of setbacks suggest otherwise.
articles.abstract: As the coronavirus keeps spreading, employers are convinced remote work has a bright future. Decades of setbacks suggest otherwise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three months after the coronavirus pandemic shut down offices, corporate America has concluded that working from home is working out. Many employees will be tethered to Zoom and Slack for the rest of their careers, their commute accomplished in seconds.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld

articles.headline: Coronavirus Is Battering Africa’s Growing Middle Class
articles.snippet: From Kenya to Nigeria, South Africa to Rwanda, the pandemic is decimating the livelihoods of the once-stable workers who were helping to drive Africa’s economic expansion.
articles.abstract: From Kenya to Nigeria, South Africa to Rwanda, the pandemic is decimating the livelihoods of the once-stable workers who were helping to drive Africa’s economic expansion.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — James Gichina started out 15 years ago as a driver shuttling travelers from the airport, worked his way up to safari guide, and with the help of some bank loans, bought two minivans of his own to ferry vacationers around.
articles.byline: By Abdi Latif Dahir

articles.headline: Supreme Court Strikes Down Louisiana Abortion Law, With Roberts the Deciding Vote
articles.snippet: The case, over a state law requiring doctors performing abortions to have admitting privileges at nearby hospitals, is the first abortion ruling since two Trump appointees joined the court.
articles.abstract: The case, over a state law requiring doctors performing abortions to have admitting privileges at nearby hospitals, is the first abortion ruling since two Trump appointees joined the court.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday struck down a Louisiana law that could have left the state with a single abortion clinic, dashing the hopes of conservatives who were counting on President Trump’s appointments to lead the court to sustain restrictions on abortion rights and, eventually, to overrule Roe v. Wade.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak

articles.headline: Supreme Court Lifts Limits on Trump’s Power to Fire Consumer Watchdog
articles.snippet: The case concerning the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau was part of a politically charged battle over presidential authority.
articles.abstract: The case concerning the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau was part of a politically charged battle over presidential authority.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that the president is free to fire the director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau without cause. The decision, rejecting a federal law that sought to place limits on presidential oversight of independent agencies, was a victory for the conservative movement to curb the administrative state.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Alan Rappeport
